stem: Complete the infection control plan for a client with an Absolute Neutrophil Count (ANC) of 450.
template: A client with severe neutropenia should be placed in {{roomtype}} and should be instructed to avoid {{food}} to minimize the risk of opportunistic infection.

options: a shared room with another oncology client

pedagogy.nclexCategory: Safety and Infection Prevention and Control

rationale.correct: ANC <500 indicates severe risk. Protective isolation (Private room, staff wearing masks if they have URI symptoms, no sick visitors) is required. Raw/Unwashed produce can harbor bacteria (like Pseudomonas) that the client's body cannot fight.
rationale.incorrect: Negative pressure is for airborne infections (like TB), the opposite of protective isolation. Cooked meat is safe.

answerBreakdown.label: Blank 1
answerBreakdown.content: The selection of "a private room (Protective Isolation)" correctly completes the clinical hypothesis based on assessment cues.

answerBreakdown.label: Blank 2
answerBreakdown.content: The selection of "fresh fruits and vegetables" correctly completes the clinical hypothesis based on assessment cues.

clinicalPearls: A fever (Temp >100.4°F / 38°C) in a neutropenic client is a MEDICAL EMERGENCY until proven otherwise.

questionTrap.howToOvercome: Remember 'B-F-F' (Berries, Flowers, Fresh-produce) are all NO-GOs for neutropenic patients due to fungal/bacterial spores.

mnemonic.title: A-N-C
mnemonic.expansion: Avoid crowd, No raw food, Clean hands.

reviewUnits.heading: Oncology Support: Managing Hematologic Toxicity
reviewUnits.body: Nurses monitor for subtle signs of infection (Neutropenic patients may not have enough WBCs to produce pus/swelling). Filgrastim (Neupogen) may be given to boost counts.
